page.title: 17FARMING
page.content: {Cattle}are kept for both milk and beef. One farmer in{Bleasby Moor}has a large herd of Friesian cows, kept for {milking.}They are kept outside in the summer. In the early part of the summer they are kept on unimproved pasture. Later on, they are put onto fields from which one or two crops of hay or silage have been taken. These fields are fertilized to promote grass-growth. The large, round bales of hay are individually wrapped in polythene bags, and stored around the edges of the field. The hay and silage are used to feed the cattle when they are kept under cover in the crew-yards during the winter. The Friesian cows bear Hereford or Charolais cross calves, which are fattened up to be sold for{beef.}A farmer at{East Torrington}keeps a herd of these on ridge and furrow pasture.
